docs.lead_paragraph: Three Southern California men, including a Los Angeles fire captain, have been charged in separate cases with sending letters that claimed to contain anthrax in the last three weeks, the authorities said today. Two men have been taken into custody, but the third fled after he was questioned by federal authorities and is considered a fugitive, a spokesman for the United States Attorney, Thom Mrozek, said.
docs.abstract: Three Southern California men, including Los Angeles fire captain, are charged in separate cases with sending letter that claimed to contain anthrax in last three weeks; fugitive Jacob de la Fuente is charged with sending envelope full of white powder to former girlfriend on Oct 17; letter forced evacuation of post office in Industry, Los Angeles suburb, after envelope tore in mail processing machine and powder spilled; Justo Saldana is arrested and accused of mailing envelope full of talcum powder to Long Beach on Oct 18, forcing officials to shut down City Hall for day; Capt Christopher Antonio Cooper of Los Angeles Fire Department is charged with sending court-ordered payment to his ex-wife's divorce lawyer in envelope containing brown powder (M)
docs.snippet: Three Southern California men, including a Los Angeles fire captain, have been charged in separate cases with sending letters that claimed to contain anthrax in the last three weeks, the authorities said today.    Two men have been taken into cust...

docs.lead_paragraph: The good news about education has become obvious: the quality of public schools is now on center stage in national politics. From George Bush and Al Gore down to aspirants for state and local office, all politicians have embraced the cause of high standards and excellence. The bad news is that the remedy everyone but teachers and pupils wants to prescribe is more testing. The mistrust of schools and teachers has become so widespread that the only politically viable solution seems to be to impose more standardized tests. Forty-nine states have now adopted curriculum standards that explicitly require testing in order to measure the performance of pupils, teachers, principals, and superintendents; by 2003, 26 states will have mandatory statewide tests for high school graduation. As a nation, we now administer at least 500,000 different kinds of standardized tests a year.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Leon Botstein, president of Bard College, says quality of public schools is now on center stage in national politics, but remedy everyone but teachers and pupils wants to prescribe is more testing; says tyranny of testing has become so intense that teachers spend more than half the year teaching specifically for tests; says mode of testing is primitive and out of date; says testing can and must be linked to learning; drawing (M)
